awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Methane Pyrolysis for High Quality Carbon Black and Low-carbon Hydrogen Production
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide low-cost hydrogen (H2) with a very low or even negative carbon dioxide (CO2) footprint at a commercial production cost reaching $1.50 per kg of H2 alongside a valuable solid carbon by-product, representing a technology advance for the American public and economy. The United States produces 10 million metric tons of hydrogen per year - 95% of it via steam methane reforming (SMR).  SMR emits 100 million tons of CO2 in the process. This represents a >$10 billion market in the US alone and an important opportunity to reduce CO2 emissions. Methane pyrolysis promises green hydrogen with >5 times less energy than water electrolysis at costs competitive with steam methane reforming by producing solid carbon instead of gaseous carbon dioxide. The solid carbon, if produced correctly, can be used in tires, batteries, and concrete. The research in this project could increase the value of the solid carbon by-product produced alongside clean hydrogen in methane pyrolysis. If successful, this technology could lead to expanded domestic production capabilities with net-zero emissions from sectors such as fertilizer, transportation (batteries, fuel cells, synthetic fuels, and tires), and heavy industry (steel and cement).

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop a novel method to tune the production of high-quality solid carbon using methane pyrolysis. Carbon black forms in pyrolysis reactors both homogeneously in the gas phase and heterogeneously on catalysts, reactor walls, and on seed particles entrained in the gas. By tuning temperature, residence time, flow profile, and seed materials, this project will result in an improved understanding of carbon precipitation and formation in methane pyrolysis reactors. This improved understanding and the development of a reactor thermochemical model will ultimately lead to better control of a process to produce high quality solid carbon that can be used in tires, batteries, and concrete.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Molten Industries was founded in 2021 by Dr. Caleb Boyd and Dr. Kevin Bush with a mission to decarbonize the world's heavy industries. Molten is revolutionizing the battery industry by producing a drop-in, lithium-ion battery grade graphite from natural gas and renewable electricity. This will allow Molten to fundamentally change the cost structure and geographic constraints of the global graphite supply chain. Additionally, their process can produce clean hydrogen as a valuable co-product which can be used to decarbonize other industries, such as steel and chemical production.

Molten’s simple process cracks methane at blazing hot temperatures into hydrogen and graphite using renewable electricity. We create no carbon dioxide, instead producing hydrogen gas and graphite that can be used in batteries. Our methane is responsibly procured from certified low-emissions sources and waste streams such as dairy farms, waste-water treatment plants, and landfills. This leads to hydrogen and carbon that are carbon-neutral or carbon-negative. Hydrogen’s versatility and potential to decarbonize heavy industries makes it essential to reaching net zero. Molten’s technology unlocks this potential.

Graphite is one of the most important minerals in batteries, and as manufacturing and EVs scale up around the world, nations are increasingly focusing on securing reliable supplies of critical materials like graphite. Diversified supply chains are a critical part of scaling up battery manufacturing and Molten’s technology gives countries like the U.S. a way to produce it with domestic feedstocks and at lower cost.

Graphite has been designated as a critical material by the United States Geological Survey and is also one of seven critical materials from 2020 to 2030 in the Department of Energy's (DOE) Critical Materials Assessment. The DOE defines Critical Materials are those raw materials which are economically and strategically important for the US energy security and economy but are not produced domestically and have a high-risk associated with their supply. Graphite is used in modern vehicles, electronics, airplanes, nuclear reactors, steel plants, hydrogen fuel cells, and importantly, lithium-ion batteries. Electric vehicle demand is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 15-20% through 2030, increasing demand for lithium ion batteries and, in turn, the graphite anode battery material that is the largest battery component by mass. Unfortunately, the United States relies entirely on imported natural flake graphite, with China being the primary supplier. In fact, China supplies 65% of global graphite production and controls 97-99% of battery-grade graphite anode processing. The supply issues have been heightened by the Russia-Ukraine conflict, both of whom were top 10 global producers of graphite prior to the war. Effective Dec. 1, 2023, China imposed further export restrictions on graphite for lithium ion batteries, making the supply crunch potentially severe. The United States Treasury also released guidance eliminating EV tax credits on EV batteries using graphite sourced from China, encouraging auto makers to find non-Chinese based graphite sources.

Molten’s graphite product, studied and developed in this project, presents an important supply of a critical material to enable the safety and prosperity of people around the globe.

Molten’s results have been publicized by well-known news outlets, including Bloomberg and The Wall Street Journal. Links to press articles can be found on Molten’s website, www.moltenindustries.com.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/10/2024
Modified by: Benjamin M Rush
